Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story: I glanced at my phone, the group chat buzzing with reminders from my stepmom: “Don’t forget, we need you here for the family holiday dinner. It means a lot to your dad.” I promised I’d be there, but my shift as a taxi driver was running late. My last fare was a family trying to make it to the train station before their holiday trip. I wanted to help them, but as I turned a corner, I hit a construction detour. The road narrowed, and suddenly, a school zone sign flashed. Kids clustered near the curb, some darting close to the street. The clock on my dashboard ticked closer to dinnertime. My step-siblings expected me to show up, to be part of the family, to prove I belonged. But behind the wheel, I was responsible for my passengers’ schedule and, more importantly, for the safety of every child on that block. My foot hovered over the brake, my mind torn between the urge to hurry and the duty to slow down. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time.
